item.title: A Brief History of Fintech's Meltdown
item.description:
Number of the Week: 700,000 (explanation below) A Brief History of Fintech's Meltdown When we started FIN in October 2020, fintech appeared to be setting the world on fire. There were so many interlocking sectors: proptech, payments, crossborder payments, Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL), insurtech, and of course cryptocurrency. PayPal was trading at nearly $200 a share, which would grow to more than $300 by July 2021 before heading back to Earth (today it‚Äôs at $86). The combination of user experience, loose regulation and a lockdown-driven need for contactless payment seemed to be ushering in a new era in how people interact with money. Private capital was flooding the sector, and even unrelated developments like government stimulus payments propelled the machine forward‚Ä¶

URL: https://fintechlatest.substack.com/p/a-brief-history-of-fintechs-meltdown?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: The Federal Reserve Did Not '‚ÄòDrink the Kool-Aid‚Äô in 2021, &

item.title: Russia's war on the world's food supply
item.description:
Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine is taking a terrible toll on Ukrainians and promoting hardship within Russia and throughout the developed world. But the biggest economic casualties are almost certainly the poorer countries that aren‚Äôt involved in the proxy conflict at all but are facing potential devastation due to the run-up in global food prices deliberately provoked by Russian policy‚Ä¶

URL: https://www.slowboring.com/p/russias-war-on-the-worlds-food-supply?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

source: The Federal Reserve Did Not '‚ÄòDrink the Kool-Aid‚Äô in 2021, &

item.title: The Japan that Abe Shinzo made
item.description:
This is the fifth and final post in my series of posts about Japan. In the first post, I lamented Japan‚Äôs low-ish living standards and called for a cash-based welfare policy. In the second, I suggested some industrial policies that Japan might use to boost growth. In‚Ä¶

URL: https://noahpinion.substack.com/p/the-japan-that-abe-shinzo-made?utm_source=substack&utm_campaign=post_embed&utm_medium=web

item.title: Gorm
item.description:
Gorm on Twitter

‚ÄúAfter years of floundering, I think I‚Äôm finally getting it: You get energy by spending it. The fuel tank metaphor is completely misleading. The body supplies energy to meet demand. The tank *expands* if you use a lot of fuel. In other words, biology is fundamentally antifragile‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/metaphorician/status/1529402899016699906

source: Best of Twitter - Week of May 30, 2022

item.description:
Ken Kocienda on Twitter

‚ÄúI see so many tweets about agile, epics, scrums, story points, etc. and none of it matters. We didn‚Äôt use any of that to ship the best products years ago at Apple.‚Äù

item.title: Ken Kocienda
item.description:
Ken Kocienda on Twitter

‚ÄúDo you know what worked? A clear vision. Design-led development. Weekly demos to deciders who always made the call on what to do next. Clear communication between cross functional teams. Honest feedback. Managing risk as a function of the rate of actual progress toward goals.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/kocienda/status/1526564985995857921

source: Best of Twitter - Week of May 30, 2022
